Wireless Communication System for Audio Signals Based on OFDM

2025 01 11

In this project, we conducted a systematic study and validation of all functional modules in an OFDM-based communication system, divided into three main tasks. First, on the MATLAB platform, we built a transmitter–channel–receiver link, simulated BER curves under various SNRs, and implemented full demodulation and decoding in a QPSK system. Next, for the OFDM system, we used periodic pilot correlation for frame synchronization and channel estimation to successfully recover received signals, fully validating each physical-layer module. Then, I innovatively introduced a dynamic delay compensation and adaptive synchronization algorithm to implement an OFDM file-transfer system over speaker–microphone audio channels, combining standard CRC checks with ACK-based retransmission to ensure data integrity and reliability. Finally, on an SDR platform, we developed a cross-device wireless OFDM transmit–receive system and employed preambles and continuous pilots with both time-domain and frequency-domain CFO compensation to correct local oscillator errors and dramatically improve signal stability and interference resilience. Test results demonstrate that this system achieves high reliability and excellent data integrity in both audio and typical wireless channel environments, laying a solid foundation for engineering applications of lightweight wireless communication systems.
